THERE ARE MORE BOTS?!?: Haha. I know bots are cool. There are bots that will tell you the weather and bots that will tell you the news. Wanna try? CHATBOTS IN DETAIL:
Coldewey breaks down the chatbot revolution in his article. %[Article: Chatbot Intro](http://bit.ly/NBCTalksBots)
![graph1](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/BenAptus/EstherBot/master/img/messaging-apps-retain-more-users-and-are-used-more-frequently-than-other-apps.jpg)
Get this, technology companies in Silicon Valley call the phenomena 'app fatigue' - people download an app and don't use it. Social apps, however, are used more often (graph). Enter chatbots, a simple AI that can do what an app can do via messaging services (like this).
To Ben chatbots have a huge potential in the legal field. Look at Ross, an artificial intelligence using IBM Servers to assist Baker and Hostetler! That bot can take plain English questions and provide an answer with citations!
What do you think? Do you believe bots will replace apps? I will collect your response! %[Article: Law Bot](http://futurism.com/artificially-intelligent-lawyer-ross-hired-first-official-law-firm/) %[I am a bot believer](postback:I_am_a_bot_believer) %[I Hate Chatbots](postback:I_hate_chatbots)

YOUTH:
![BolinFam](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/BenAptus/EstherBot/master/img/bolinfam.jpg)
Ben grew up in Saint Joseph, Missouri with his two sisters, and a tight-knit extended family.
 Ben's youth made him something of a factotum of experiences. During that time, Ben was recognized as a Voice of Democracy by the Veterans of Foreign Wars, he attended Missouri Boys State, competed in debate, and even directed his high school's first musical! %[High School Musical](postback:high_school_musical) %[Go Back](postback:Go_Back)
HIGH SCHOOL MUSICAL:
Ben spent much of his youth performing on a stage. His acting career culminated in his performance at the Missouri State Theater's production of You Can't Take It With You. He then became a student director for his high school's production of Annie. This was a huge undertaking for a school with very limited resources.
But Ben worked with small teams to make one of the best shows the town had ever seen! It was this experience that helped him realize his passion for problem solving and leadership that would later culminate in his undergraduate career. Would you like to hear about Ben's undergraduate career? Or chat with Ben? %[Physics Degree](postback:Physics_Degree) %[Chat With Ben](postback:Chat_With_Ben) %[Go Back](postback:Go_back)
UNDERGRADUATE:
![BolinGrad](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/BenAptus/EstherBot/master/img/BolinGrad.PNG)
Ben graduated with a degree in physics from the University of Missouri with minors in mathematics and east asian studies. He is currently studying at the University of Missouri - Kansas City School of Law with an emphasis in intellectual property. WHY JAPANESE?!:
On a trip to DisneyWorld his first semester of undergrad, Ben visited the Japanese exhibit. Impressed, Ben resolved to study Japanese. However, it was too late to take the first year Japanese course. Not dissuaded, he self studied, and skipped the introductory classes to take Japanese year 2 that fall!
However, his true test would come when he traveled to Japan. %[Oh Do Tell](postback:oh_do_tell)
OH DO TELL:
Ben has spent nearly six months in Japan. He lived with two AMAZING host families.
![114](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/BenAptus/EstherBot/master/img/1003215_10201463161916810_2120169399_n.jpg)
In Iida, Japan he volunteered at the community center, and soon set to work creating the Winter Christmas Park. There he was, standing at an abandoned elementary school no bigger than a gas station, surrounded by Japanese locals. The mission was to transform this decrepit building into a winter wonderland of lights.
Ben was humbled by his failures due to language barrier. He placed lights in the wrong place, and would get in the way more than he could help. %[What did he do](postback:what_did_he_do)
WHAT DID HE DO:
Ben rose to the challenge, studying fiercely each night the words and phrases he heard but couldn't understand. He asked for more clarification more often. He made friends. And before Ben knew it the old decrepit building was covered in lights and a buzz with children, performers, and food!
The night the lights were officially turned on, Ben and the Mayor of Iida hit the button together to the cheers of the community. This experience taught Ben the value of listening, community, and an appreciation for public service. %[Has he done more?](postback:Has_He_Done_More?)
HAS HE DONE MORE?:
Yes! Ben has translated for Studio Rikka on the Time of Eve (a movie with over five international awards) english release. He has even performed traditional Japanese puppetry (人形浄瑠璃) as a main singer.
![Taiyu](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/BenAptus/EstherBot/master/img/1173868_10201457992907588_550633403_n.jpg)
Connect with Ben and talk about (or in) Japanese! %[Chat With Ben](postback:Chat_With_Ben) %[Go Back](postback:Go_back)
INVOLVEMENT:
During his four years at Mizzou, Ben was involved in the University of Missouri student government known as the Missouri Students Association (MSA). There, he represented the University of Missouri in Washington DC to representatives, he even engaged other student government leaders at the SEC Exchange Conference.
![BolinMSA](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/BenAptus/EstherBot/BenAptus-patch-4/img/485984_10200771790879552_718071570_n.jpg)
Ben was elected the Senate Speaker of the MSA Senate, where he worked tirelessly to serve the 71 senators. Ben's administration successfully lobbied for road improvements from the city, donated 3,500 pounds of food, and even recommended a new Vice Provost of Affairs. Not to mention managing a 1.7 million dollar budget. %[Wow Great Team](postback:Wow_Great_Team)
WOW GREAT TEAM:
Ya! They absolutely were. Ben learned a lot from them. He learned the value of communication, the sacrifice of determination, and alot about remembering to have fun.
But the projects, accomplishments (and failures!) don't stop there. You should talk with Ben about his involvement during his undergrad to learn more! %[Chat With Ben](postback:Chat_With_Ben) %[Go Back](postback:Go_back)
WHY PHYSICS:
Discovery, for Ben, was a young boy turning over rocks to see what was underneath. Growing up Ben's passion for exploration and discovery was unapparent to him. His concept of knowledge and experience were limited to getting Pikachu to level 60 on the Pokemon video games.
Despite Ben's nerdiness, he maintained a strong curiosity and eagerness to understand the people and world around him. His final year of high school, he took his first physics class. It was an absolute challenge for him. Simple concepts were difficult for Ben, and he loved it.
He explored 'the effects of friction' he discovered 'when two trains would crash'. It was hard, but rewarding. Most importantly, Ben realized his innate passion for discovery and exploration. He decided physics was the best medium to realize that passion. %[Why Not Engineering](postback:why_not_engineering)
WHY NOT ENGINEERING:
Good question. Engineering also helps explain the unexplained. But Physics is the building block to most all engineering. Ben's adviser explained it best, 'a physics degree grants the ability to learn quickly and think critically.' With a physics degree, you can quickly learn almost any concept.
This is why Ben chose physics over any other science or engineering degree, because he could learn pieces of each degree. AND he got to discover more of the science behind the concepts taught in class! You should chat with Ben about his Physics degree! %[Chat With Ben](postback:Chat_With_Ben) %[Go Back](postback:Go_back)

LAW DEGREE: Ben is ranked 27 out of 145 in his class. He will be starting his 2nd year of law school this fall. What would you like to chat about? %[Why Law School](postback:Why_Law_School) %[Classes](postback:classes) %[Extracurriculars](postback:extracurriculars)
WHY LAW SCHOOL:
Ben didn't even think about law school until he encountered a patent attorney. During his entrepreneurship, Ben met with a patent lawyer named Matt Kitzi. Ben was amazed by what Matt did everyday. Matt learned about new inventions, researched them, and then sought the best protection for innovators.
Ben loves to discover new things, and being a patent lawyer was a great medium to continually learn, discover, and help innovators like him! %[How does Ben feel now](postback:how_does_ben_feel_now)
HOW DOES BEN FEEL NOW:
After some law school experience, Ben believes the practice of law is like his physics degree. In physics, he was given limited variables and told 'solve for x'. In the practice of law, a lot of what they do is 'solve for x' but also 'give every possible method to achieve x.'
Ben doesn't feel out of his element, but rather right where he was to begin with! Would you like to talk to Ben about his decision to go to law school? %[Chat With Ben](postback:Chat_With_Ben) %[Go Back](postback:Go_back)
CLASSES:
Ben received the top section grade in his Cyberlaw and Information Policy course, where he completed his research and writing paper. The paper has since been selected for publication with the UMKC Law Review. The piece describes the commensurate relationship between law firm size and cybersecurity requirements.
Ben is also taking the standard course load including contracts and property. This summer, Ben will be taking a class on law firm entrepreneurship. This fall, Ben will be enrolling in intellectual property courses. Would you like to chat with Ben about his courses? %[Chat With Ben](postback:Chat_With_Ben) %[Go Back](postback:Go_back)
EXTRACURRICULARS:
Ben enjoys involvement in several areas of the law school. Ben is a staff member of the UMKC Law Review. He is also a rising member of the Intellectual Property Negotiation Team, who won nationals in 2014 and 2015! Ben is also the vice-president of the Intellectual Property Society.
Ben was the treasurer of the Legal Technologists Society (LTS) as well, a group that seeks to promote responsible integration between lawyers and technology. LTS hosted an e-discovery event and a careers in technology event last year. Would you like to talk to Ben about his extracurriculars in law school? %[Chat With Ben](postback:Chat_With_Ben) %[Go Back](postback:Go_back)
EXPERIENCE: Sure, would you like to hear about his legal experience or technical experience? %[Legal Experience](postback:legal_experience) %[Technical Experience](postback:technical_experience) %[Leadership Experience](postback:leadership_experience)
LEGAL EXPERIENCE:
Ben is a volunteer for the Kansas City Volunteer Lawyers and Accountants for the Arts (KCVLAA) a group dedicated to educating and assisting artists in the Kansas City area. Ben has helped attorneys present to artists about contract, copyright, and trademark law. He has also assisted in client meetings. %[KCVLAA](http://www.kcvlaa.org/)
This summer and fall Ben is working for the City of Kansas City. There he is assisting the Kansas City Land Bank in contract law and doing some corporate prosecution! Besides that, Ben has filed two patents on thermoelectric devices during his entrepreneurship. Chat with Ben about his developing legal experience. %[Chat With Ben](postback:Chat_With_Ben) %[Go Back](postback:Go_back)
TECHNICAL EXPERIENCE: As a lab technician and as founder of his own company, Ben has technical experience in thermoelectrics, mathematica, and.. chatbots? Ben has also demonstrated his technical experience at Hackathons! However, his physics degree has equipped him to pick up any technology quickly. Which would you like to learn about? %[Thermoelectrics](postback:thermoelectrics) %[Hackathons](postback:hackathons)
THERMOELECTRIC:
Thermoelectrics are devices made up of two dissimilar metals (one with more electrons than the other), when you apply a heat gradient (a difference in temperature) between the metals, electrons jump from one metal to the other creating electricity. Thermoelectrics are very similar to solar panels (sister technology).
Ben and his company used rapid prototyping and real world power plants to test their invention which used thermoelectrics for waste heat conversion. Ben has also used and adapted these devices as a lab assistant for the Institute for Nuclear Renaissance. You should talk to Ben about thermoelectrics! %[Chat With Ben](postback:Chat_With_Ben) %[Go Back](postback:Go_back)

HACKATHONS:
Ben competed in two hackathons, and has made it to the final round in both. What is a hackathon? Hackathons are competitions where students are given 48 hours to solve complex problems. Students are then judged based on their inventions. Ben competed at the Washington University Hackathon and Hack Mizzou.
Ben and his team were state champions in 2015 at Hack Mizzou, and named finalists at Washington University. Ben and his team invented solar trackers, and a legal TLDR program extension for chrome! Check out the Legal TLDR page on the hackathon's website! %[Site: Legal TLDR](http://devpost.com/software/wuhack) %[Chat With Ben](postback:Chat_With_Ben) %[Go Back](postback:Go_back)
LEADERSHIP EXPERIENCE:
Ben has led students and teams to reach their full potential. Ben managed 70 senators as the Senate Speaker of his student government to pass a 1.7 million dollar budget. Ben has also lead a small multidisciplinary team to file two patents on a thermoelectric invention.
In law school he was treasurer of the Legal Technologists Society. They put on two large events this year, with over two dozen in attendance. He leads with energy, poise, and believes in 'leading by example.' %[A Leadership Story](postback:A_Leadership_Story) %[Go Back](postback:Go_Back)
A LEADERSHIP STORY:
In undergrad, Ben recognized there were many problems persisting on campus. Organizations needed more involved members. Standing committees needed more student input. Ben believed a Think Tank was necessary to solve these issues. Ben reached out and received a flood of questions from many campus organizations. Ben then brought the team together. He encouraged all voices to speak. When the think tank started its discussions Ben selected members based on their individual strengths. Sometimes, that meant seeking an opinion from someone who had no idea about the problem. Or asking for an idea from members who rarely spoke. Bringing in those rarely heard voices highlighted major unforeseen sub-issues that were critical. The ideas shared were immediate. Institutional questions such as the role of subcommittees were redefined. The committee even helped grapple the phenomena of colleges stressing extracurricular activities over academic prowess to new students.
In total, the committee recommended and discussed over 70 issues from across campus. And led to many structural changes across campus. Without bringing out and playing the strengths of those individuals, the think tank would not have succeeded. You should talk to Ben about leadership for even more examples and stories! %[Chat With Ben](postback:Chat_With_Ben) %[Go Back](postback:Go_back)
